awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Unlocking "forbidden" optical transitions in nanostructures using light with orbital angular momentum
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical abstract: 
Light with orbital angular momentum (also called "vortex beams" and "twisted light") has generated considerable recent interest because of applications in high-resolution imaging and high-bandwidth communications, but little is known about how twisted light interacts with solid matter. This research explores the use of twisted light to generate new "twisted" quantum electron excitations in nanostructures. Experiments are performed by illuminating cylindrical nanostructures such as rings and dots with light that has tunable orbital angular momentum in order to excite, measure, and control twisted electronic states. The new quantum states accessed in this research could be used in future technologies such as high-bandwidth data storage, computing, and communications. Additionally, this work will be integrated into a new service learning course at the University of Denver in which students will bring these research ideas into neighborhood middle and high schools through hands-on demonstrations.

Technical abstract: 
The objective of this project is to demonstrate and measure unexplored orbital angular momentum (OAM)-activated optical transitions in semiconductor nanostructures. Experiments are performed on quantum rings, dots and wells in order to: 1.) Demonstrate that different orbital states are accessed with twisted light by studying the OAM dependence of transmission spectra; 2.) Measure the dephasing of distorted (OAM-excited) electron and hole wavefunctions with zero spatial overlap, including varying the distribution between center-of-mass and relative-motion angular momentum that is only possible with OAM excitation; and 3.) Control the relaxation of orbital states with OAM-tunable optical pumping. These experiments are enabled by novel multidimensional spectroscopy in which both OAM and wavelength are simultaneously resolved.

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this NSF CAREER project were to demonstrate new tools for characterizing the angular momentum of optical vortices, and to explore their use in optical transitions and spectroscopy of nanostructures. Along the way, we discovered that optical vortices move in accordance with hydrodynamics -- similarly to how a leaf moves along the surface of a river in response to the local fluid velocity and as vortices move in Bose Einstein Condensates (BEC) and superfluid helium. We aggressively pursued this exciting direction, summarized by these three primary results:

1. We demonstrated two methods for quantitative measurement of the orbital angular momentum of light -- a simple method requiring only a lens and a camera, and a powerful one that provides the full angular momentum spectrum;

2. We showed experimentally and theoretically that optical vortex motion and interactions can be explained by hydrodynamics; and

3. We identified a way to measure the geometric phase (an important analog to quantum geometric phase, with connections to topological phase used in topological quantum computing) of complex vortex systems to include arbitrary starting points on the Poincare sphere, including non-geodesic paths.

Important advances were also made in multidimensional spectroscopy that can be applied widely across disciplines that use this technique, including new methods for fast acquisition of homogeneous linewidths and absolute phase calibration.

This funding resulted in 19 published papers in peer-reviewed physics journals, with another paper in review. The PI gave 17 invited seminar talks on this research and undergraduate or graduate student researchers presented 26 talks or posters at physics conferences.

The impact of this project was very broad and extended beyond the research results. Five graduate students were trained and graduated (two MS and three PhD), another three current graduate students were supported, and nine undergraduate students were mentored in spectroscopy and photonics research, including five women. This project also supported educational programming and community engagement through development of a community-engaged ?Light-Matter Interaction? physics class, in which the PI combined quantum optics and semiconductor physics concepts with training and opportunities to do community outreach. The class has now run three times, and each time students 1.) design and build hands-on physics demonstrations related to light-matter interaction, 2.) develop a plan for how to deliver their demo in an engaging and hands-on way, and 3.) share their demonstrations with elementary school students. The PI also recruited and trained students from the Society of Physics Students (SPS) undergraduate club at the University of Denver to run small-group demonstrations for students at a variety of venues. More than 1000 K-12 students were impacted.
